repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body: Wrap the query with passthrough sequence

comment_data.body:
nitpicking: when `TMUX=""` (not `nil`), this will also evaluate as truthy. (But it's quite unlikely to happen unless users set `$TMUX` manually) Consider:

```diff
-os.getenv('TMUX')
+#(os.getenv('TMUX') or "") > 0
```

or any equivalent ways: e.g. `vim.fn.empty(vim.env.TMUX) == 0`. EDIT: I do see in many other places (e.g. #26281), not only for this PR, we already had similar conditions.

The convention is that `$TMUX` is only ever set when a tmux session is active. If a user has `$TMUX` set to an empty string outside of a tmux session then they did so manually (or it is the result of a buggy configuration). In either case, it's not something I think we need to handle here.

comment_regular_data.body:
> tmux already handles OSC 11 queries natively

Hmm that's strange, because I tested `printf '\x1b]11;?\x07'; cat` in tmux 3.3_a on Arch Linux and it didn't print anything.

> The passthrough sequence was not used intentionally, since tmux already handles OSC 11 queries natively 

It didn't work for me (tmux 3.2a on Ubuntu 22.04)

> Most users will not have allow-passthrough enabled, so this results in a worse user experience overall.

there are other places where you used passthrough, so I thought it was fine.

As of https://github.com/tmux/tmux/commit/a41a92744188ec5c8a8d4ddc100ec15b52d04603, tmux queries the parent terminal. This commit was on Jan 3, 2023 (almost a year ago), but has not been released yet.

Prior to that commit it looks like tmux only responded to OSC 11 if the background was first set inside tmux.

> > The passthrough sequence was not used intentionally, since tmux already handles OSC 11 queries natively
> 
> It didn't work for me (tmux 3.2a on Ubuntu 22.04)
> 
> > Most users will not have allow-passthrough enabled, so this results in a worse user experience overall.
> 
> there are other places where you used passthrough, so I thought it was fine.

This is the context in the PR description I would have liked to see :) The use of passthrough sequences in other places was only done because tmux did not handle those escape sequences at all. That's not the case for OSC 11, hence why it wasn't used here.

This is an unfortunate situation though. I'm hesitant to add a passthrough because as soon as a new version of tmux is released the passthrough will need to be removed. But on the other hand, most users are probably using a tagged release of tmux, where the passthrough is still necessary.

Maybe a middle ground can be that we leave the passthrough for now, with a comment saying that it should be removed when the next version of tmux is released.
Thanks for the comment. I should have mentioned that. The suggested solution sounds good.
I set tmux keybind `bind -n M-] next` and `allow-passthrough`, with this commit, every time I open nvim, it prints `11;rgb:0000/0000/0000`. Is this expected behavior?
That seems to be a bug of tmux.

> That seems to be a bug of tmux.

I can confirm that running tmux#bdf8e614 (HEAD right now), the issue is not happening anymore, did not bother to bisect the exact commit though.

I suppose this is not really the place for this, but I've been using the HEAD of Tmux for some time to get background auto-dection working in Neovim 0.9 inside Tmux.

It works perfectly with 0.9.5, but it does no longer work in nightly. I would guess that this commit is the culprit?

I see that `allow_passthrough` is mentioned in the comments here, but neither with it on or off, I can get it to work with Neovim nightly and Tmux HEAD (nor in fact with 3.3a).

Is there a combination of settings for Tmux HEAD needed for it to work in Neovim Nightly?

title: fix(defaults): background detection in tmux
